newsitem.title: USA: US OPTIONS FOCUS/IBM, Iomega and gold stocks.
newsitem.headline: US OPTIONS FOCUS/IBM, Iomega and gold stocks.

text.p: Call options on International Business Machines Corp were heavily traded as IBM shares were among the few to gain on Friday amid a broad market selloff, traders said.

IBM July 100 calls, August 105 calls and August 110 calls were the busiest options on the Chicago Board Options Exchange as the stock rose more than 4 points to about 104 despite a 100-point fall in the Dow Jones Industrials .DJI.
Similarly, Iomega Corp calls were also near the top of the most-actives list at CBOE and the American Stock Exchange as the stock gained more than 2 to above 24.
A brokerage firm trader said strong buying interest was boosting volume in those options.
However, many traders were not very optimistic about a sustained rally in those shares.

"I think the tech stocks in general are done for," said Bill Yates of DYR Associates. He noted that IBM had been a laggard during the tech stocks' recent rally and was now just playing catch-up, while Iomega stock was always a wild card.
"IBM was pretty much the one big stock that hadn't moved, so for some reason they're going back and picking IBM today," he said.
"Oftentimes it shows an end of a rally when they come back and pick up the stocks in the group that didn't rally previously," he added.
Yates recommended buying puts now to lock in profit if a trader had IBM or any tech stocks which, led by Microsoft Corp, turned down today after a long bull run.
"There's not much bottom picking to be done," he said.
Jay Shartsis, director of options trading at R.F. Lafferty & Co, was also skeptical about the few buoyant tech stocks.
"They're building in so much positive expectation," he said. "At this point you can start to disappoint."
IBM was due to announce its earnings on Monday. According to the research firm First Call, analysts on average expect $1.42 a share versus $1.26 a year earlier.
But Shartsis said meeting or exceeding such expectations did not really matter in the current over-extended market.
"Just look at Microsoft," he said, referring to the stock's selloff despite a sharp rise in earnings reported Thursday that met expectations.
Gold stocks were one sector that was just basing and beginning to move upward, he said.
"Gold stocks -- everything else, watch out," he said.
Shartsis said Placer Dome and Newmont Mining Corp were two of the major stocks in the sector.
The trouble with gold stocks for option traders was that they have low volatility, both actual and implied, Yates said.
"It's best to sell options (primarily via buy-write against a stock position) when stocks moved down," he said.
"But incredibly, when gold went down, the stocks didn't create any high volatility," he added. "So there's little volatility to sell."
On the other hand, slow anticipated gains meant outright call buying would be a fight against time decay, he said.
-- Shin Kishima/Chicago Derivatives Desk ((312-408-8750))
